DOC.HEAD: Government Says Evidence Links Threatening Letters
DOC.BYLINE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with court members receiving threatening letters. ^By JAMES ROWLEY
DOC.TEXT: Colleagues of a federal appellate judge who was killed by a parcel bomb similar to one that fatally injured a civil rights lawyer have since received threatening letters, sources said Friday. The Justice Department, meanwhile, said four threatening letters delivered this week bore physical evidence linking them to the bombs. The letters to the judges were among those that surfaced after parcel bombs killed 11th Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert S. Vance on Dec. 16 and Savannah, Ga., alderman and attorney Robert E. Robinson two days later, said the sources. A letter addressed to Vance was also among those delivered, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said he was unaware that letters had been delivered to judges on the 11th Circuit. But he said there was ``solid evidence'' on four threatening letters delivered this week linking them to the parcel bombs that killed Vance and Robinson as well as two others found this week. Parcel bombs were also found at the the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the NAACP and the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta. Both were defused without incident. Runkel declined to describe the common characteristics of the letters and the parcel bombs. But stamps, typing or other markings on the packages and letter envelopes may give FBI crime lab specialists important clues. Comparing the typing on the letters and packages may enable the FBI to determine if the same typewriter was used to address the parcels and write the letters. Runkel said the physical evidence may also provide a link to four other letters sent in August that declared war on the 11th Circuit. The earlier letters, sent from Atlanta, threatened poison gas attacks on population centers until ``widespread terror'' forces the 11th Circuit to ``adopt the impartial and equitable treatment of all.'' Before Vance's death, the 11th Circuit had 10 active judges. The Atlanta-based court considers appeals from federal district courts in Florida, Georgia and Alabama. While the FBI continued its investigation of the bombings in the deep South, a state judge was seriously injured by a parcel bomb in his apartment in Hagerstown, Md. The FBI sent agents to assist local police and the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms to investigate the blast that injured Circuit Judge John Corderman. The FBI-led investigation has been concentrating on possible racial motivations for the killings in Georgia and Alabama. Agents have been combing Vance's docket to determine if any of his decisions, particularly in civil rights cases, may have motivated the slaying. In September, Vance wrote an opinion in a Jacksonville school desegregation case that was a victory for the NAACP. A three-judge panel of the 11th Circuit unanimously reversed a lower court's ruling that Jacksonville could stop busing students because the school system was racially integrated. Robinson had represented the NAACP on an unrelated school desegregation case involving Savannah schools. Investigators have found physical evidence linking the bombs, which were made with nails and explosive material. The bomb parcels all were mailed from towns in Georgia. Vance was killed in his suburban Birmingham, Ala., home after opening a package. Robinson was fatally injured by a bomb that exploded when he opened a similar package sent to his law office. Meanwhile, Savannah police said that security would be tight for Robinson's funeral Saturday. Benjamin Hooks, director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is expected to speak at the service. The Justice Department said Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer, James P. Turner, acting head of the civil rights division, and William Lucas, director of the department's Office of Liaison Services would attend the funeral.
